Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Expectation2: Teach Torah and Jewish law to children and adults.
Situation2: An optional, drop-in adult education class on a general topic is scheduled.
Story: I watched my younger brother strap on his helmet, eyes shining with excitement as he eyed the steep, uneven ramp in our backyard. He’d been practicing for weeks, but this trick was new—and dangerous. As his sibling, I felt a knot of worry tighten in my stomach. I was supposed to look out for him, to make sure he didn’t get hurt. But my phone buzzed with a reminder: the adult education class at the synagogue was starting in twenty minutes. As the rabbi, I was expected to be there, to teach Torah and guide the community, even if the class was optional and attendance was unpredictable. I could see the anticipation on my brother’s face, and I knew he wanted me to watch, maybe even to cheer him on. But I also pictured the expectant faces of my congregants, waiting for me to share wisdom and tradition. My heart pounded as I stood between the ramp and the responsibility, torn by the weight of both roles, unsure which path to take.
